channel.title: NInvoke C++ library: manipulate Java programs from C++
channel.description:
NInvoke is a C++ library that allows manipulation of Java programs directly from C++.
Created this for my own usage, but who knows where it all leads.
Here's a demonstration video of it's usage: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=t-3n1kxTw1g

item.title: NInvoke C++ library: manipulate Java programs from C++
item.dc:creator: @_s11 s1gma
item.description:
@_s11 wrote:

[quote=“The Enforcer, post:9, topic:381509”][quote author=Graham link=topic=477321.msg3499125#msg3499125 date=1297593906]

ROFL

You don’t know what an initializer does do you? rofl

NICore core;
core.initialize();

Andddddddddddddd
rofl @ naming:

NIJavaStaticness

You’re retarded, seriously.

I don’t know what an initializer does? Do you have some fucking strict rule what a method called ‘initialize’ can do and what it can’t? In this case it loads the needed dlls at runtime and sets everything up to make NICore usable.

Now, about the naming. All my classes have a NI prefix. Got a problem with that? Classes that represent something in the JVM have the prefix NIJava. Got a problem with that?

I think his point is that you should use a constructor so it’s called automatically - instead of relying on the user of the library to call the initialize() method (maybe they’ll forget or do it more than once).

Also, I think the point about the name was the “staticness” part. In general classes should represent something… but I certainly don’t have a clue what it represents with the name “staticness”.
[/quote]

It’s an enumeration class.[/quote]
wow

edit: way to pollute the global namespace

Read full topic

ROFL

You don’t know what an initializer does do you? rofl

NICore core;
core.initialize();

Andddddddddddddd
rofl @ naming:

NIJavaStaticness

You’re retarded, seriously.

I don’t know what an initializer does? Do you have some fucking strict rule what a method called ‘initialize’ can do and what it can’t? In this case it loads the needed dlls at runtime and sets everything up to make NICore usable.

Now, about the naming. All my classes have a NI prefix. Got a problem with that? Classes that represent something in the JVM have the prefix NIJava. Got a problem with that?
[/quote]

I think his point is that you should use a constructor so it’s called automatically - instead of relying on the user of the library to call the initialize() method (maybe they’ll forget or do it more than once).

Also, I think the point about the name was the “staticness” part. In general classes should represent something… but I certainly don’t have a clue what it represents with the name “staticness”.[/quote]

It’s an enumeration class.

item.title: NInvoke C++ library: manipulate Java programs from C++
item.dc:creator: @Graham Graham
item.description:
@Graham wrote:

[quote=“The Enforcer, post:6, topic:381509”][quote author=Evil_ link=topic=477321.msg3494416#msg3494416 date=1297200015]
ROFL

You don’t know what an initializer does do you? rofl

NICore core;
core.initialize();

Andddddddddddddd
rofl @ naming:

NIJavaStaticness
[/quote]

You’re retarded, seriously.

I don’t know what an initializer does? Do you have some fucking strict rule what a method called ‘initialize’ can do and what it can’t? In this case it loads the needed dlls at runtime and sets everything up to make NICore usable.

Now, about the naming. All my classes have a NI prefix. Got a problem with that? Classes that represent something in the JVM have the prefix NIJava. Got a problem with that?[/quote]

I think his point is that you should use a constructor so it’s called automatically - instead of relying on the user of the library to call the initialize() method (maybe they’ll forget or do it more than once).

Also, I think the point about the name was the “staticness” part. In general classes should represent something… but I certainly don’t have a clue what it represents with the name “staticness”.

item.title: NInvoke C++ library: manipulate Java programs from C++
item.dc:creator: @The_Enforcer The Enforcer
item.description:
@The_Enforcer wrote:

abraham2119:

so basically it’s a shitty wrapper around jni…woop de fucking doo

JNI is one of the APIs it uses, but I can tell you that it isn’t just a simple wrapper for JNI. Even if it was so you should know that it’s better to build abstraction on JNI rather than deal with countless method calls that are all very similar. Way to flame, though.

Read full topic
